continue
The <tt>continue</tt> statement has the following basic syntax:
{ANY_CODE} continue;

If used inside of a statement that forms a loop (for, repeat, while or do / until), it will immediately end the current iteration and jump back to the beginning of the loop starting a new iteration and omitting any code that comes after the continue within the loop. It can also be used within the with statement, where it will cause the code to skip to the next instance and run again. Note that if continue is used outside of any of these contexts it will give an error.
Below is an example of use in a <tt>for</tt> loop:

{ANY_CODE} var _val = 0;
for (var i = 0; i < 10; i += 1)
{nbsp_x4}{
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} if (val_array[i] <={nbsp_x1}0)
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} continue;
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} }
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} _val += val_array[i];
{nbsp_x4}}
draw_text(32, 32, "Positive Values Total = " + string(_val));
Below is an example of use in a while loop:

{ANY_CODE} var file = file_text_open_read("Game_Data.txt");
var _num = 0;
while (!file_text_eof(file))
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} var _s ={nbsp_x1}file_text_readln(file);
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} if (_s == "")
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} continue;
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} }
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x2}str[num++] = _s;
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} }
file_text_close(file);

{ANY_CODE} do
{nbsp_x4}{
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} var _x = random(room_width);
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} var _y = random(room_height);
{nbsp_x4}if (instance_position(_x, y, obj_Enemy)
{nbsp_x8}{
{nbsp_x8}continue;
{nbsp_x8}}
{nbsp_x1} {nbsp_x1} instance_create_layer(_x, _y, "Instances", obj_Enemy);
{nbsp_x4}}
until (instance_count(obj_Enemy) >= 10);
